results.headline: Coop and Papa, Manning Up in Good Times and Bad

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cooper & Hemingway: The True Gen

results.summary_short: “Cooper & Hemingway” examines the friendship between Gary Cooper and Ernest Hemingway, who shared a love of the outdoors but had strikingly different personalities.

results.headline: A Thriller Armed With Thought

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain Phillips

results.summary_short: Based on a true story of a hijacking by Somali pirates, “Captain Phillips” begins as something of a procedural about men at work and morphs into a jittery thriller.

results.headline: Ah, Those Giddy Teenage Pool Parties
results.display_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All the Boys Love Mandy Lane

results.summary_short: In “All the Boys Love Mandy Lane,” whose commercial release has long been awaited, a teenage beauty’s getaway weekend turns violent.

results.headline: Jealousy and Spite as Game Figurines

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Charisma

results.summary_short: In “Zero Charisma,” an obsessive gamer is unsettled by a new player who has a popular blog and a girlfriend.

results.headline: A Bizarre Scavenger Hunt in San Francisco

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Institute

results.summary_short: “The Institute” wavers between documentary and exploratory simulation in exploring an alternate-reality game.

results.headline: Oh, Hey, Romeo, What’s Up?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Romeo and Juliet

results.summary_short: Adapted by Julian Fellowes of “Downton Abbey” fame, “Romeo & Juliet,” starring Hailee Steinfeld, won’t sound all that familiar to students of Shakespeare’s text.

results.headline: All He’s Got to Do Is Save the World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Machete Kills

results.summary_short: In the violence-filled “Machete Kills,” Danny Trejo is called upon to ward off catastrophe.

results.headline: A Life Ravels Out, and a Brooding Family Sets Forth

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As I Lay Dying

results.summary_short: James Franco directs and stars in the first film adaptation of Faulkner’s “As I Lay Dying,” a book that has long been considered unfilmable.

results.headline: Afterlife? What Afterlife?
results.display_title: I Will Follow You Into the Dark

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Will Follow You Into the Dark

results.summary_short: In “I Will Follow You Into the Dark,” Mischa Barton is a religious skeptic whose boyfriend mysteriously disappears.

results.headline: Toughing It Out, Against All Odds
results.display_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister and Pete

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Inevitable Defeat of Mister and Pete

results.summary_short: “The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete” follows two boys through one tough Brooklyn summer.

results.headline: Whoa, Are Snow White and Mulan Really Working the Street?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Escape From Tomorrow

results.summary_short: In “Escape From Tomorrow,” a family vacation at a Disney park takes on a macabre cast after the husband and father receives bad news.

results.headline: From Rock Album to Stage Musical

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Broadway Idiot

results.summary_short: The documentary “Broadway Idiot” observes the metamorphosis of “American Idiot” from record to stage show, and of Billie Joe Armstrong from rock star to stage actor.

results.headline: Libidinous Specters in the House

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Team One

results.summary_short: “Ghost Team One” is a potty-mouthed variation on the “Paranormal Activity” subgenre.

results.headline: Linear Genius, Bold and Transformative
results.display_title: Design Is One: Lella & Massimo Vignelli

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Design Is One: Lella & Massimo Vignelli

results.summary_short: “Design Is One” recounts how Lella and Massimo Vignelli introduced bold new elements to graphic design.

results.headline: Lamentation for a Home of Punk Rock

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of CBGB

results.summary_short: “CBGB” is an elegy to that defunct nightclub in the East Village, and its owner and presiding spirit, Hillel Kristal.

results.headline: Where Séances Go Badly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cassadaga

results.summary_short: “Cassadaga,” set in a Florida town that is a hub for psychics, centers on a deaf artist looking for solace after her sister’s death.

results.headline: The Wages of Pop Music

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grace Unplugged

results.summary_short: “Grace Unplugged” takes its title character to Los Angeles for a career in the music industry and, ultimately, some life lessons from the Bible.

results.headline: The Trip Up the Mountain That Left 11 Dead

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Summit

results.summary_short: “The Summit,” which recreates a perilous climb from 2008, accepts the age-old truth that if there is a mountain, someone will try to reach its peak.

results.headline: Fighting School Bullies With a Camera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dirties

results.summary_short: In “The Dirties,” two best friends who love making and talking about movies confront high school bullying.

results.headline: Between Earth and Heaven

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gravity

results.summary_short: In Alfonso Cuarón’s “Gravity,” two astronauts marooned in space struggle for survival in rapidly changing circumstances.
